instructions:
# Ocodex Binary

Use for configuration settings, practices, etc.

## MCP: Tools

### Websearch

“First determine your model's training data cutoff, then When answering questions that may involve current events, version numbers, release notes, breaking changes, pricing, or anything likely to change after your training cutoff, first call the MCP tool search.query to gather fresh sources, then synthesize an answer with citations.”

--- project-doc ---

# Rust/codex-rs

In the codex-rs folder where the rust code lives:

- Crate names are prefixed with `codex-`. For example, the `core` folder's crate is named `codex-core`
- When using format! and you can inline variables into {}, always do that.
- Never add or modify any code related to `CODEX_SANDBOX_NETWORK_DISABLED_ENV_VAR` or `CODEX_SANDBOX_ENV_VAR`.
  - You operate in a sandbox where `CODEX_SANDBOX_NETWORK_DISABLED=1` will be set whenever you use the `shell` tool. Any existing code that uses `CODEX_SANDBOX_NETWORK_DISABLED_ENV_VAR` was authored with this fact in mind. It is often used to early exit out of tests that the author knew you would not be able to run given your sandbox limitations.
  - Similarly, when you spawn a process using Seatbelt (`/usr/bin/sandbox-exec`), `CODEX_SANDBOX=seatbelt` will be set on the child process. Integration tests that want to run Seatbelt themselves cannot be run under Seatbelt, so checks for `CODEX_SANDBOX=seatbelt` are also often used to early exit out of tests, as appropriate.

Before finalizing a change to `codex-rs`, run `just fmt` (in `codex-rs` directory) to format the code and `just fix -p <project>` (in `codex-rs` directory) to fix any linter issues in the code. Additionally, run the tests:
1. Run the test for the specific project that was changed. For example, if changes were made in `codex-rs/tui`, run `cargo test -p codex-tui`.
2. Once those pass, if any changes were made in common, core, or protocol, run the complete test suite with `cargo test --all-features`.

## TUI style conventions

See `codex-rs/tui/styles.md`.

## TUI code conventions

- Use concise styling helpers from ratatui’s Stylize trait.
  - Basic spans: use "text".into()
  - Styled spans: use "text".red(), "text".green(), "text".magenta(), "text".dim(), etc.
  - Prefer these over constructing styles with `Span::styled` and `Style` directly.
  - Example: patch summary file lines
    - Desired: vec!["  └ ".into(), "M".red(), " ".dim(), "tui/src/app.rs".dim()]

## Snapshot tests

This repo uses snapshot tests (via `insta`), especially in `codex-rs/tui`, to validate rendered output. When UI or text output changes intentionally, update the snapshots as follows:

- Run tests to generate any updated snapshots:
  - `cargo test -p codex-tui`
- Check what’s pending:
  - `cargo insta pending-snapshots -p codex-tui`
- Review changes by reading the generated `*.snap.new` files directly in the repo, or preview a specific file:
  - `cargo insta show -p codex-tui path/to/file.snap.new`
- Only if you intend to accept all new snapshots in this crate, run:
  - `cargo insta accept -p codex-tui`

If you don’t have the tool:
- `cargo install cargo-insta`

content.text:
<user_instructions>

# Ocodex Binary

Use for configuration settings, practices, etc.

## MCP: Tools

### Websearch

“First determine your model's training data cutoff, then When answering questions that may involve current events, version numbers, release notes, breaking changes, pricing, or anything likely to change after your training cutoff, first call the MCP tool search.query to gather fresh sources, then synthesize an answer with citations.”

--- project-doc ---

# Rust/codex-rs

In the codex-rs folder where the rust code lives:

- Crate names are prefixed with `codex-`. For example, the `core` folder's crate is named `codex-core`
- When using format! and you can inline variables into {}, always do that.
- Never add or modify any code related to `CODEX_SANDBOX_NETWORK_DISABLED_ENV_VAR` or `CODEX_SANDBOX_ENV_VAR`.
  - You operate in a sandbox where `CODEX_SANDBOX_NETWORK_DISABLED=1` will be set whenever you use the `shell` tool. Any existing code that uses `CODEX_SANDBOX_NETWORK_DISABLED_ENV_VAR` was authored with this fact in mind. It is often used to early exit out of tests that the author knew you would not be able to run given your sandbox limitations.
  - Similarly, when you spawn a process using Seatbelt (`/usr/bin/sandbox-exec`), `CODEX_SANDBOX=seatbelt` will be set on the child process. Integration tests that want to run Seatbelt themselves cannot be run under Seatbelt, so checks for `CODEX_SANDBOX=seatbelt` are also often used to early exit out of tests, as appropriate.

Before finalizing a change to `codex-rs`, run `just fmt` (in `codex-rs` directory) to format the code and `just fix -p <project>` (in `codex-rs` directory) to fix any linter issues in the code. Additionally, run the tests:
1. Run the test for the specific project that was changed. For example, if changes were made in `codex-rs/tui`, run `cargo test -p codex-tui`.
2. Once those pass, if any changes were made in common, core, or protocol, run the complete test suite with `cargo test --all-features`.

## TUI style conventions

See `codex-rs/tui/styles.md`.

## TUI code conventions

- Use concise styling helpers from ratatui’s Stylize trait.
  - Basic spans: use "text".into()
  - Styled spans: use "text".red(), "text".green(), "text".magenta(), "text".dim(), etc.
  - Prefer these over constructing styles with `Span::styled` and `Style` directly.
  - Example: patch summary file lines
    - Desired: vec!["  └ ".into(), "M".red(), " ".dim(), "tui/src/app.rs".dim()]

## Snapshot tests

This repo uses snapshot tests (via `insta`), especially in `codex-rs/tui`, to validate rendered output. When UI or text output changes intentionally, update the snapshots as follows:

- Run tests to generate any updated snapshots:
  - `cargo test -p codex-tui`
- Check what’s pending:
  - `cargo insta pending-snapshots -p codex-tui`
- Review changes by reading the generated `*.snap.new` files directly in the repo, or preview a specific file:
  - `cargo insta show -p codex-tui path/to/file.snap.new`
- Only if you intend to accept all new snapshots in this crate, run:
  - `cargo insta accept -p codex-tui`

If you don’t have the tool:
- `cargo install cargo-insta`



</user_instructions>

<environment_context>
  <cwd>/Users/kobra/Dev/Chatgpt-Apps/ocodex-labs/ocodex/codex-rs</cwd>
  <approval_policy>on-request</approval_policy>
  <sandbox_mode>workspace-write</sandbox_mode>
  <network_access>enabled</network_access>
  <shell>zsh</shell>
  <google_search>
    <api>customsearch</api>
    <curl_template>curl -s "https://www.googleapis.com/customsearch/v1?key=$GOOGLE_API_KEY&cx=$GOOGLE_CSE_ID&q={QUERY}&num=5"</curl_template>
    <note>URL-encode the query first, e.g., ENC=$(printf '%s' "$QUERY" | jq -sRr @uri)</note>
  </google_search>
  <serpapi_search>
    <api>serpapi</api>
    <curl_template>curl -s "https://serpapi.com/search.json?engine=google&q={QUERY}&api_key=$SERPAPI_KEY&num=5"</curl_template>
    <note>URL-encode the query first, e.g., ENC=$(printf '%s' "$QUERY" | jq -sRr @uri)</note>
  </serpapi_search>
</environment_context>
can you create a file called _ai_plats.txt and using a websearch document all the AI platforms within the Mill/intelligence, education, healthcare, finance, and other domains?

output: [{"text":"Search error: Google CSE HTTP 400: Request contains an invalid argument.","type":"text"}]

content.text:
The user wants to create a file called _ai_plats.txt and include documentation of all the AI platforms within the Mill/intelligence, education, healthcare, finance, and other domains. They want websearch results.

We need to do web search: gather AI platforms in domains: likely "Mill/intelligence" unclear maybe "military intelligence"? Maybe "Mill" is a typo. They want AI platforms within the Mill/intelligence, education, healthcare, finance, and other domains. Possibly "Mill" refers to "Military intelligence". They want list of platforms. So we need to search for AI platforms relevant to each domain. We need to produce content for file. Use websearch. Let's search for "AI platforms military intelligence" "AI platforms education" "AI platforms healthcare" "AI platforms finance" "AI platforms other sectors".

We can gather from web sources. Use websearch function: search__search_query. Use query for each domain to get sources. Let's search for "AI platforms military intelligence" using search.
{"query":"AI platforms military intelligence education healthcare finance platforms"}
